text:
Has anyone hired a freelance editor?

I’ve always been hesitant to outsource anything other than writing as it can take awhile for someone to fully grasp brand voice, reflect our style guide and know some of the nuances of our content. However, these are two areas of need right now (editing + writing briefs, including SEO research) so I’d love to hear about your experiences, how you vetted candidates and how you structured fees.

elements.text:
Has anyone hired a freelance editor?

I’ve always been hesitant to outsource anything other than writing as it can take awhile for someone to fully grasp brand voice, reflect our style guide and know some of the nuances of our content. However, these are two areas of need right now (editing + writing briefs, including SEO research) so I’d love to hear about your experiences, how you vetted candidates and how you structured fees.

text:
I have hired a small agency to help me write a course and a series of SEO articles.  I don’t really outsource the whole strategy (we had reasons for doing the course and going after those keywords) but I let the agency have freedom on the course design and final structure and the outlines for the articles list (more than I give most freelancer writers since I knew/trusted their work)...if you find a multifaceted agency and give them some direction/tools, they should be able to help strategize how to execute those projects or help you reach your goals (esp. Seo-focused ones. That’s probably the easiest to consider outsourcing, I think). But I’ve never had an outside agency heavily influenced my company’s overall strategy—but strategizing and taking over large pieces of it, yes! I do it More on a project by project basis to move faster and spend my budget on things that will move the needle but that I don’t have time for. (Budget matters. Strategy costs more than giving writers outlines...)

Happy to recommend them if you’re interested in talking to them. They’re great people even if they end up not being a fit.

text: <@U01694YQ3FX> that’d be great, can you DM me? We don’t need to outsource strategy as a whole, more the instruction to implement it (eg receiving a list of working title ideas and writing full briefs for each piece). So, strategic thinker/understands how to craft a brief or outline for a piece that will meet goals, but not the strategy itself if that makes sense.

elements.text: that’d be great, can you DM me? text: Sure! For clarity this is a small agency vs single writer but they honestly do great work :)

elements.text: Sure! For clarity this is a small agency vs single writer but they honestly do great work :)

text:
<@URB31QKM4> I'm a bit biased, since I'm a solo content strategist and do a bit of freelance writing too.

When it comes to building out a thorough content strategy, it is all about having a dialed-in process. (It also helps if you have a niche since your learnings compound faster)

However, if you are nervous about hiring this out, one thing you can do is to have this person write some initial articles / content assets first.  I've personally done this a few times. It can work well for both people and speed up the content strategy process.

text: Also a big fan of Sprout Social! :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I’m just here in solidarity for you and anyone else who needs help writing content briefs (we’re in the process of hiring for my team, but in the meantime, I’ve gotta keep client trains moving). So much to do (good problem), not enough brainpower to go around.
